topic_knowledge_points: A graph G = (V, E) has vertices and edges (directed or undirected); simple graphs have no parallel edges or self-loops.
Key notions: adjacency, incidence, degree/indegree/outdegree, path, cycle, connected components, trees/forests, spanning trees.

Graph ADT exposes Vertex/Edge with incidentEdges, isAdjacentTo, endVertices/opposite, vertices(), edges(), insert/remove operations; directed variants add isDirected, origin, dest, insertDirectedEdge.
Edge list: store all vertices and edges; simple, O(n+m) space; incidentEdges/isAdjacentTo are O(m).
Adjacency list: each vertex keeps list of incident edges; O(n+m) space; incidentEdges O(deg(v)), isAdjacentTo O(min(deg(v),deg(w))).
Adjacency matrix: n×n table of adjacencies; O(n^2) space; isAdjacentTo O(1); incidentEdges O(n); vertex insert/delete O(n^2).
Depth-First Search (DFS): recursive exploration; labels discovery (tree) edges and back edges; discovery edges form a spanning tree of the connected component.
DFS runs in O(n+m) with adjacency lists; solves connectivity, spanning tree, connected components, path/cycle finding.
Decorator pattern: attach attributes (visited/status) to vertices/edges; generic DFS with overridable hooks (startVisit, traverseDiscovery, traverseBack, finishVisit, isDone).
Breadth-First Search (BFS): explores level by level; discovery edges form BFS tree; level i equals shortest number of edges from start; cross edges between same/adjacent levels; O(n+m).
Reachability, strongly connected, directed cycle; directed DFS/BFS traverse only outgoing edges.
Transitive closure: Floyd–Warshall (dynamic programming) in O(n^3); repeated DFS O(n(n+m)), good for sparse graphs.
Strong connectivity test: DFS from s in G and in reverse(G); if both visit all vertices then strongly connected.
Topological sorting (DAGs): Kahn’s algorithm using indegrees stack/queue, O(n+m); DAG iff a topological order exists.
Weighted graphs define path length by sum of edge weights; Dijkstra’s algorithm (nonnegative weights) grows a cloud using a min-priority queue and edge relaxation D[z] = min(D[z], D[u]+w(u,z)).
Dijkstra with adjacency lists and heap runs in O((n+m) log n); correctness relies on no negative-weight edges.
Cut property: minimum-weight edge across any cut appears in some MST.
Kruskal: sort edges by weight; add if it connects two different clusters (union-find); O(m log n) with heap + union-find.
Prim–Jarník: grow a tree from an arbitrary root using a min-priority queue keyed by best incident edge; O((n+m) log n).
